content: hi everyone why lock here welcome back
recently plaid the company behind folk art modpodge and a lot of other products
that we love sent me a box of stuff to use and review I thought I would take a
look at all the technical paints that were in there try them out on some of my
projects maybe retrofit and give you my honest impressions of them and a couple
of months plaid will be releasing mod podge ultra and it comes in these
spritzer bottles I was wondering if they'd be a decent replacement for PVA
glue and water to attach and seal tree leaf flocking so I took out some tree
armatures attached clumps of moss using hot glue and then spritzed it till
visibly soaked now I wanted to test both fine flocking and clump flocking so I've
got my homemade sawdust flock as well as some leftover foam clump tree scatter
from huge miniatures also I'm curious what effect this will have on different
shades so I'm gonna toss this on the tree don't really care about the final
look here what I'm interested in is adhesion and finish and color
so first adhesion after a day to dry it looks good a little spongy but that's
the case with PVA glue to after the first application everything sticks well
and the vibrancy of the greens hasn't changed which is a problem that I've had
with PVA and water so I doused it again came back a day later and voila rock
hard as expected colors look good too so if you've tried
to do trees and had a hard time getting your glue water mixture just right or
just don't want to go to the hassle this stuff might be a usable surrogate for
you performs as I hoped it would these are some flash paints they're iridescent
metallic and they kind of change color with the angle of the light cool concept
I wasn't overly impressed with these unfortunately the coverage is very very
thin I can't imagine how many coats it would take to brush up to a solid sheen
but for paints that are finicky with coverage and airbrush sometimes eases
the pain and the blue one here caught my eye for potential use on alpha Legion
Space Marines so I tried it out one of these was applied over a grey base coat
and the other over a blue base coat they do shimmer it doesn't come through on
camera but they absolutely do have that color-changing metallic effect I really
had to feather it with the airbrush it probably
took about ten light coats to get here so mixed bag
these glazes are interesting they're used to make things look antique I've
always struggled to get a good sandstone so I want to try this dark brown one
first I took a hunk of extruded polystyrene then rolled it with some
balled up aluminum foil to texturize and then picked out some divots with pliers
because the instructions say to let this stuff collect where it wants to
important for the overall look then just two coats of linen just a neutral light
tannish Brown sort of color and then we're supposed to brush on the glaze and
then while wet wipe off the excess kind of like wood stain it's got a weird
oily texture to it so I wipe off the excess and yeah the detail is
accentuated and this isn't as rich of brown as I was hoping but that's beside
the point what I'm looking for here is what this
has done for the texture understanding that I'm not using this for its intended
purpose it does fill surface divots I think you could get the same results
with a simple wash of watered-down acrylic craft paint I mean I did back
for the exterior stucco of the walls in episode 38 with the in so this performs
as advertised but I think for us to reign crafters a wash will do just as
well although I will say this stuff is thick and oily and it doesn't run so if
you want to wash vertical surfaces and not have Runnels of liquid well then
there's a small advantage here this two-part kit right here is first of
several this is for moss so there's a dark and a light green texture paint so
I took a dungeon tile and dabbed on some healthy splotches of the dark green and
then per the instructions a few spots of the light green so I aim for like 50%
coverage with it and kind of use the brush to help mix
the two in some spots I also did one of my stone pillars few hours later it's
dry and we get this in my opinion a very good result definitely cells as moss I
like it I recommend this gets me excited for the concrete kit so yeah again
there's a light and a dark I'm gonna retro create the power station from
episode 59 remember we had this thing on a large cardboard rectangle painted up
to look like concrete so let's try the texture paint again dab it on the light
color are not stroke but dab it on fairly healthy amount
and then now it back and dab with the dark gray being more aggressive in some
places maybe twisting the brush to help the to mix in a few spots
about an hour later and concrete I went a little too heavy on the dark color I
should have used a lot less maybe been more irregular with it but the texture
is good again I like this the granules might be a little large and scale for
what I'm doing here with miniature terrain but you definitely get what's
advertised which is a convincing concrete texture and this has me very
excited for the rust kit there's a dark brown and a terracotta kind of orangey
shade I'm gonna take one of the soup can tower sections that we just built in
episode 115 for the modular industrial walkways first I'll cover up those
copper splotches that I put on and get get back to straight gunmetal and then
in truth I played with this stuff before filming I mean I did that for all of
this and I did find that having a slightly damp brush not soaked but
ringed out helps the paint to be just runny enough to flow down a surface and
give us Runnels which is just what I want so I hit both ends with the dark
color and it kind of got away with me on the lower base but that's okay it looks
like the tank is leaking or something very grim darken and then the orange
color again dabbing in some random spots to complement here it is wet
and here it is a few hours later awesome I am impressed with this easily my
favorite of this this whole batch of products easy way to take this terrain
one level higher no pun intended and frosted glass these are intended to be
used on glass and baked so on a scrap bit of glass I painted on a spectrum
just all the colors they sent me this is it after one coat pretty thin so I'll
let it dry and here it is after two coats then into the oven you're supposed
to put it in with the oven cold start a heat to 350 and bake at 350 for 30
minutes and here it is after it looks identical to before it went in except
that it's been cured so it's really durable I cannot scrape it off I don't
know I expected it to be semi-transparent but I can't even see
through it maybe that's the intended look I mean I
only did two thin coats and I let him dry an hour each but I don't use real
glass in my projects anyway not real crazy about how this came out maybe I
used it wrong not sure so final verdict first we'll do the may so the frosted
glass paints not crazy bottom I don't use glass in my work anyway the antique
glazes for terrain making for what we do a paint wash is just as good and the
flash paints they're hard to use tricky to get the effect right but if you do it
looks great and now the recommends the Mod Podge ultra spray worked great for
foliage I like it it's gonna be a little more expensive than good old white glue
and water but I also found it to be noticeably more effective less flock
falling off and the moss concrete and rust kits my favorite of the bunch
love them thanks for joining me here some recommended viewing and a community
showcase I'll see you next time
